docs.lead_paragraph: The trial of the Texas financier R. Allen Stanford on charges of defrauding investors out of $7 billion as part of a massive Ponzi scheme will begin in January 2011, a federal judge ruled Thursday, The Associated Press reported.

headline.main: Judge Sets January 2011 Trial in Stanford Case

docs.abstract: Texas financier R. Allen Stanford's trial on charges he bilked investors out of $7 billion as part of a massive Ponzi scheme will begin in January 2011, a federal judge ruled Thursday.
docs.snippet: Texas financier R. Allen Stanford's trial on charges he bilked investors out of $7 billion as part of a massive Ponzi scheme will begin in January 2011, a federal judge ruled Thursday.

docs.abstract: The fact that patented drugs can be priced so much lower abroad has long irritated American politicians and the general public, an economist writes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Does the Senate health care bill put us on a path toward real reform, or does it head us down a valley in which reform will be less likely?

docs.lead_paragraph: The current health care bill falls a long way short of ideal, but it is better than anything that seemed possible just a few years ago.

docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders seem willing to give Senator Ben Nelson anything to win his support of health care reform — except restrictions on insurance coverage for abortions.

headline.main: A Race to Win One More Vote for Health Bill

byline.original: By JEFF ZELENY  and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Liberals like Senator Bernard Sanders are signaling that they have compromised enough to win over moderates.

headline.main: Liberal Revolt on Health Care Stings White House

docs.lead_paragraph: After a phone call from President Obama, and a round of applause from his Senate colleagues, Senator Russ Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, said Thursday night that he would cast a rare vote in support of allowing consideration of the annual military spending bill to thwart Republican efforts to delay the Democrats' health care legislation. Mr. Feingold, a staunch opponent of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, routinely votes against military spending measures.
docs.abstract: Pres Obama prevails upon Sen Russ Feingold, staunch opponent of wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, to vote in support of military spending bill in order to foil Republicans' hopes of blocking that bill in order to delay final vote on health care legislation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Service Employees International Union, two of the nation's biggest labor organizations and strong allies of the Obama administration, have withheld their endorsements of the Senate health care bill now that the Senate has dropped the public option. Instead, they are vowing to renew their fight for a public option -- a government-run insurance program -- and for other provisions once the Senate approves its final bill and negotiators begin melding it with the House bill, which does provide for the option.
docs.abstract: AFL-CIO and Service Employees International Union, both strong allies of Obama administration, are withholding their endorsements of Senate version of health care legislation and intend to push to restore dropped public option in final version of legislation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If there were any doubts that Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine has earned a special place in the hearts of Democrats by being the only Senate Republican to vote for any form of the major health legislation, just consider how she spent her Thursday: First she attended a meeting at the White House for roughly 80 to 90 minutes, a good portion of it one-on-one with President Obama. Later, she and Mr. Obama had a half-hour follow-up call.

headline.main: Snowe Gets Some Close Attention From Obama

docs.abstract: A long visit to the White House and then a call from the president on health care for Olympia Snowe.
docs.snippet: A long visit to the White House and then a call from the president on health care for Olympia Snowe.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
